{{Use mdy dates|date=January 2018}} {{Infobox winter storm | name = January 2018 North American blizzard | image = Early January 2018 Nor'easter 2018-01-04 1345Z.jpg | alt = Satellite image of a sprawling cloud structure centered horizontally. Cuba is visible on the bottom-left of the image while the eastern United States is visible on the left. | caption = [[GOES-16]] satellite image of the blizzard [[Explosive cyclogenesis|rapidly deepening]] off the [[Northeastern United States]] at 13:45 [[Coordinated Universal Time|UTC]] (8:45 a.m [[Eastern Standard Time (North America)|EST]]) on January 4, 2018. | type = [[Extratropical cyclone]]
[[Nor'easter]]
[[Bomb cyclone]]
[[Winter storm]]
[[Ice storm]]
[[Blizzard]] | formed = {{start date|2018|01|02}} | dissipated = {{end date|2018|01|06}} | RSI = 2.55 | lowest pressure = 949 | lowest temperature = | tornadoes = | fujitascale = | tornado duration = | 1-min winds = 80 | gusts = {{convert|203|km/h|mph|abbr=on}} in [[Saint-Joseph-du-Moine, Nova Scotia]] | maximum snow = Snowfall – {{convert|24.0|in|cm|abbr=on}} in [[Bathurst, New Brunswick]]
Ice – {{convert|0.5|in|cm|abbr=on}} in [[Brunswick, Georgia]] | power outages = ≥ 300,000 | total fatalities = 22 confirmed | damages = $1.1 billion (2018 [[United States dollar|USD]]){{cite web |title=Global Catastrophe Recap - May 2018 |first1=Aon |last1=Benfield |url=http://thoughtleadership.aonbenfield.com/Documents/20180607-ab-analytics-if-may-global-recap.pdf|publisher=Aon Benfield |accessdate=9 June 2018}} | affected = [[Southeastern United States]], [[Northeastern United States|Northeast]], [[New England]], [[Atlantic Canada]] | current advisories = | enhanced = yes | notes = Part of the '''[[2017–18 North American winter]]''' }} The '''January 2018 North American blizzard''' was a powerful [[blizzard]] that caused severe disruption along the [[East Coast of the United States]] and [[Atlantic Canada|Canada]]. It dumped [[snow]] and [[ice]] in places that rarely receive wintry precipitation, even in the winter, such as [[Florida]] and [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]], and produced snowfall accumulations of over {{convert|2|ft|cm}} in the [[Mid-Atlantic states]], [[New England]], and Atlantic Canada. The storm originated on January 3 as an area of low pressure off the coast of the Southeast. Moving swiftly to the northeast, the storm explosively deepened while moving parallel to the Eastern Seaboard, causing significant snowfall accumulations. The storm received various unofficial names, such as ''Winter Storm Grayson'', ''Blizzard of 2018'' and ''Storm Brody''. The storm was also dubbed a "historic [[bomb cyclone]]".{{Cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/capital-weather-gang/wp/2018/01/04/historic-bomb-cyclone-unleashes-blizzard-conditions-from-coastal-virginia-to-new-england-frigid-air-to-follow/ |title=Historic ‘bomb cyclone’ unleashes blizzard conditions from coastal Virginia to New England. Frigid air to follow. |last=Samenow |first=Jason |date=January 4, 2018 |work=Washington Post |access-date=January 4, 2018}} On January 3, blizzard warnings were issued for a large swath of the coast, ranging from [[Norfolk, Virginia]] all the way up to [[Maine]]. Several states, including [[North Carolina]], [[New Jersey]], [[New York (state)|New York]], and [[Massachusetts]] declared [[state of emergency|states of emergency]] due to the powerful storm. Hundreds of flights were canceled ahead of the blizzard. Overall, 22 people were confirmed to have been killed due to the storm, and at least 300,000 residents in the [[United States]] lost power in total. ==Meteorological synopsis== {{storm path|January 2018 Nor'easter track.png}} Early on January 1, [[Weather Prediction Center|the Weather Prediction Center (WPC)]] began to anticipate the possibility of a northward-tracking [[low-pressure area|area of low pressure]] that would bring wintry precipitation to much of the [[East Coast of the United States]] in the first week of January, exacerbating an [[2017–18 North American cold wave|extended period of anomalously cold weather]]. Due to [[numerical weather models|modeling]] confining of precipitation to relatively narrow bands at the time, initial forecasts on the storm's impacts were uncertain.{{cite web|last1=Petersen|first1=Daniel|title=Probabilistic Heavy Snow and Icing Discussion 08:17Z January 1, 2018|url=http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/discussions/hpcdiscussions.php?disc=qpfhsd&version=6&fmt=reg|website=Winter Weather Forecast Discussion|publisher=National Weather Service's Weather Prediction Center|accessdate=January 3, 2018|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180103232805/http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/discussions/hpcdiscussions.php?disc=qpfhsd&version=6&fmt=reg|archive-date=January 3, 2018|location=College Park, Maryland|date=January 1, 2018}} The storm's development was forecast to originate from the eastward progression of a [[shortwave (meteorology)|shortwave trough]] originating from the northern [[Rocky Mountains]],{{cite web|last1=Pereira|first1=Frank|title=Probabilistic Heavy Snow and Icing Discussion 21:16Z January 1, 2018|url=http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/discussions/hpcdiscussions.php?disc=qpfhsd&version=5&fmt=reg|website=Winter Weather Forecast Discussion|publisher=National Weather Service's Weather Prediction Center|accessdate=January 3, 2018|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180103234014/http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/discussions/hpcdiscussions.php?disc=qpfhsd&version=5&fmt=reg|archive-date=January 3, 2018|location=College Park, Maryland|date=January 1, 2018}} strengthening due to the presence of a longwave trough situated over the [[Eastern United States]].{{cite web|last1=Petersen|first1=Daniel|title=Probabilistic Heavy Snow and Icing Discussion 08:39Z January 1, 2018|url=http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/discussions/hpcdiscussions.php?disc=qpfhsd&version=4&fmt=reg|website=Winter Weather Forecast Discussion|publisher=National Weather Service's Weather Prediction Center|accessdate=January 3, 2018|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180103234710/http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/discussions/hpcdiscussions.php?disc=qpfhsd&version=4&fmt=reg|archive-date=January 3, 2018|location=College Park, Maryland|date=January 1, 2018}} However, as the anticipated event drew closer, the system's genesis grew increasingly complex with the development of two separate disturbances in the [[jet stream]] over the upper [[Mississippi Valley]] and the eastern extent of the Rocky Mountains; these two would shape the eventual coverage of wintry precipitation associated with the storm.{{cite web|last1=Musher|first1=Michael|title=Probabilistic Heavy Snow and Icing Discussion 21:45Z January 2, 2018|url=http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/discussions/hpcdiscussions.php?disc=qpfhsd&version=3&fmt=reg|website=Winter Weather Forecast Discussion|publisher=National Weather Service's Weather Prediction Center|accessdate=January 3, 2018|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180103235726/http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/discussions/hpcdiscussions.php?disc=qpfhsd&version=3&fmt=reg|archive-date=January 3, 2018|location=College Park, Maryland|date=January 2, 2018}} As the troughs pushed eastward, [[frontogenesis]] along the trough and a resulting increase in moisture allowed for [[freezing rain]] to commence over areas of northern [[Florida]] and southern [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]] early on January 3.{{cite web|last1=Jewell|first1=Ryan|title=Mesoscale Discussion 1|url=http://www.spc.noaa.gov/products/md/2018/md0001.html|website=Storm Prediction Center|publisher=National Weather Service|accessdate=January 4, 2018|location=Norman, Oklahoma|date=January 3, 2018}} Later that day, rapid [[cyclogenesis]] led to the formation of the forecast low-pressure area north of the [[Bahamas]] and east of [[Jacksonville, Florida]],{{cite web|last1=Musher|first1=Michael|title=Probabilistic Heavy Snow and Icing Discussion 21:21Z January 3, 2018|url=http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/discussions/hpcdiscussions.php?disc=qpfhsd&version=3&fmt=reg|website=Winter Weather Forecast Discussion|publisher=National Weather Service's Weather Prediction Center|accessdate=January 3, 2018|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180104000655/http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/discussions/hpcdiscussions.php?disc=qpfhsd&version=0&fmt=reg|archive-date=January 3, 2018|location=College Park, Maryland|date=January 3, 2018}} with cloud cover quickly expanding to the north and east ahead of the storm's center; consequently, the WPC began issuing regular storm summaries at 21:00 [[Coordinated Universal Time|UTC]] (4:00 p.m. [[Eastern Standard Time (North America)|EST]]) on January 3.{{cite web|last1=Hamrick|first1=David|title=Storm Summary Number 1 for Eastern U.S. Coastal Winter Storm|url=http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/winter_storm_summaries/storm23/stormsum_1.html|website=Storm Summary Message|publisher=National Weather Service's Weather Prediction Center|accessdate=January 4, 2018|location=College Park, Maryland|date=January 3, 2018}} After forming, the [[extratropical cyclone]] continued to [[explosive cyclogenesis|explosively deepen]], tracking northward parallel to the [[East Coast of the United States|United States East Coast]].{{cite web|last1=Tate|first1=Jennifer|title=Storm Summary Number 2 for Eastern U.S. Coastal Winter Storm|url=http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/winter_storm_summaries/storm23/stormsum_2.html|website=Storm Summary Message|publisher=National Weather Service's Weather Prediction Center|accessdate=January 4, 2018|location=College Park, Maryland|date=January 3, 2018}} By the morning of January 4, the powerful storm system had deepened by 53 [[bar (unit)|mbar]] ([[pascal (unit)|hPa]]; 1.57 [[inches of mercury|inHg]]) in 21 hours—one of the fastest rates ever observed in the Western Atlantic{{cite news|last1=Samenow|first1=Jason|title=Historic ‘bomb cyclone’ unleashes blizzard conditions from coastal Virginia to New England. Frigid air to follow.|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/capital-weather-gang/wp/2018/01/04/historic-bomb-cyclone-unleashes-blizzard-conditions-from-coastal-virginia-to-new-england-frigid-air-to-follow/|accessdate=January 4, 2017|work=The Washington Post|agency=The Washington Post|publisher=The Washington Post|date=January 4, 2017|location=Washington, D.C.}}—to a [[barometric pressure|pressure]] of 952 mbar (hPa; 28.11 inHg), with a coastal [[cold front]] focusing heavy snowfall and [[thundersnow]] along immediate coastal regions.{{cite web|last1=Kong|first1=Kwan-Yin|title=Storm Summary Number 4 for Eastern U.S. Coastal Winter Storm|url=http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/winter_storm_summaries/storm23/stormsum_4.html|website=Storm Summary Message|publisher=National Weather Service's Weather Prediction Center|accessdate=January 4, 2018|location=College Park, Maryland|date=January 4, 2018}} The drop in pressure was over twice the threshold (24 mbar (hPa; 0.71 inHg) in 24 hours) for [[bombogenesis]].{{cite news|last1=Sneed|first1=Annie|title=What Is This "Bomb Cyclone" Threatening the U.S.?|url=https://www.scientificamerican.com/article/what-is-this-ldquo-bomb-cyclone-rdquo-threatening-the-u-s/|accessdate=January 5, 2018|work=Scientific American|agency=Scientific American|publisher=Nature America, Inc.|date=January 3, 2018|format=Edited interview transcript}} Onshore, the inland extent of wintry precipitation gradually increased as the storm intensified.{{cite web|last1=Jewell|first1=Ryan|title=Mesoscale Discussion 5|url=http://www.spc.noaa.gov/products/md/2018/md0005.html|website=Storm Prediction Center|publisher=National Weather Service|accessdate=January 4, 2018|location=Norman, Oklahoma|date=January 4, 2018}} As the day progressed, the development of several intense snowbands allowed for heavy snowfall rates of up to {{convert|3|in|cm|abbr=on}} per hour over [[New England]],{{cite web|last1=Peters|first1=Jeff|last2=Karstens|first2=Chris|title=Mesoscale Discussion 6|url=http://www.spc.noaa.gov/products/md/2018/md0005.html|website=Storm Prediction Center|publisher=National Weather Service|accessdate=January 4, 2018|location=Norman, Oklahoma|date=January 4, 2018}}{{cite web|last1=Karstens|first1=Chris|title=Mesoscale Discussion 8|url=http://www.spc.noaa.gov/products/md/2018/md0008.html|website=Storm Prediction Center|publisher=National Weather Service|accessdate=January 4, 2018|location=Norman, Oklahoma|date=January 4, 2018}} which were enhanced further by the [[advection|influx]] of warm low-level air due to the cyclone's circulation.{{cite web|last1=Peters|first1=Jeff|last2=Karstens|first2=Chris|title=Mesoscale Discussion 7|url=http://www.spc.noaa.gov/products/md/2018/md0007.html|website=Storm Prediction Center|publisher=National Weather Service|accessdate=January 4, 2018|location=Norman, Oklahoma|date=January 4, 2018}} The storm bottomed out at a pressure of 950 mbar (hPa; 28.05 inHg) when it was centered about {{convert|120|mi|km|abbr=on}} southeast of [[Nantucket, Massachusetts|Nantucket Island]]. The cyclone's intensity held steady as it moved north into the [[Bay of Fundy]] late on January 4.{{cite web|last1=Gallina|first1=Gregg|title=Storm Summary Number 6 for Eastern U.S. Coastal Winter Storm|url=http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/winter_storm_summaries/storm23/stormsum_6.html|website=Storm Summary Message|publisher=National Weather Service's Weather Prediction Center|accessdate=January 5, 2018|location=College Park, Maryland|date=January 4, 2018}} Afterwards, it began weakening and ultimately dissolved into a [[trough (meteorology)|trough]] on January 6. ==Preparations and impact== {| class="wikitable" style="float:right; margin:1em; margin-top:0;" |+ style="text-align:center;"| All weather alerts issued by the NWS from January 2–5 in the Eastern U.S. during the winter storm | colspan="6" style="text-align:center;"| [[File:January 2018 North American blizzard watches and warnings.png|225px]] |- | style="width:10px; height:10px; background:#FF4500;" | ||  [[Blizzard warning]] |- | style="width:10px; height:5px; background:hotPink;"| ||  [[Winter storm warning]] |- | style="width:10px; height:10px; background:#7B68EE;" | ||  [[Winter weather advisory]] |} The blizzard produced snowfall and other forms of frozen precipitation across much of the United States [[East Coast of the United States|Eastern Seaboard]]. As of the WPC's fifth winter storm summary, the highest official snowfall amount recorded is {{convert|17.0|in|cm|abbr=on}} in [[Cape May Court House, New Jersey]]; however, a snowfall total of {{convert|52|cm|in}} was reported [[Bathurst, New Brunswick]]. Freezing rain totals peaked at {{convert|0.5|in|cm|abbr=on}} in [[Brunswick, Georgia]] and near [[Folkston, Georgia]].{{cite web|last1=Kong|first1=Kwan-Yin|title=Storm Summary Number 5 for Eastern U.S. Coastal Winter Storm|url=http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/winter_storm_summaries/storm23/stormsum_5.html|website=Storm Summary Message|publisher=National Weather Service's Weather Prediction Center|accessdate=January 4, 2018|location=College Park, Maryland|date=January 4, 2018}} At least twenty-two fatalities were attributed to the storm, including at least eight car accident-related deaths. At least 4,020 flights were cancelled across the United States, with a majority of cancellations caused by the extensive winter storm.{{cite news|url=http://abcnews.go.com/US/snowy-bomb-cyclone-hitting-northeast-forcing-3000-flight/story?id=52132537|title=At least 6 dead as monster 'bomb cyclone,' thundersnow wallop Northeast|last1=Allen|first1=Karma|work=ABC News|accessdate=January 5, 2018|publisher=American Broadcasting Company|agency=ABC News|last2=Golembo|first2=Max|last3=Griffin|first3=Melissa}} Insurers estimate that claims relating to coastal flooding from the storm will be more than those from snow-related damage.{{cite news|title=Insurers brace for coastal flood losses from US ‘bomb cyclone’|url=https://insuranceday.maritimeintelligence.informa.com/ID055417/Insurers-brace-for-coastal-flood-losses-from-US-bomb-cyclone?src=SOCIAL&account_type=TWITTER&account_name=insurance_day&date=20180108&linkId=46703260|accessdate=8 January 2018|work=Insurance Day|date=5 January 2018}} ===Southeastern United States=== ====Florida and Georgia==== [[File:SCSnow (39516895881).jpg|thumb|left|Snow cover at the National Guard armory in [[North Charleston, South Carolina]].]] Several campuses of [[Florida A&M University]] and [[Florida State University]], as well as a number of other Florida universities and school districts, announced closures for January 3.{{cite news|last1=Teproff|first1=Carli|title=Some lucky students in Florida will be getting ‘snow days’ due to winter blast|url=http://www.miamiherald.com/news/state/florida/article192663584.html|accessdate=January 4, 2018|work=Miami Herald|agency=Miami Herald|publisher=Miami Herald|date=January 2, 2018|location=Miami, Florida}} [[Governor of Georgia]] [[Nathan Deal]] declared a [[state of emergency]] for 28 [[List of counties in Georgia (U.S. state)|counties]]. Accumulating snowfall fell in [[Savannah, Georgia]] for the first time since February 2010,{{cite news|last1=Bynum|first1=Russ|title=Florida, Southeast seaboard hit by frosty storm|url=https://www.mercurynews.com/2018/01/03/florida-southeast-seaboard-hit-by-frosty-storm/|accessdate=January 4, 2018|work=The Mercury News|agency=Associated Press|publisher=Digital First Media|date=January 3, 2018|location=Savannah, Georgia}} while [[Tallahassee, Florida]] received measurable frozen precipitation, though barely measurable and short-lived, for the first time since 1989.{{cite news|last1=Ellen Klas|first1=Mary|title=It’s snowing in Tallahassee for the first time in three decades|url=http://www.miamiherald.com/news/state/florida/article192708034.html|accessdate=January 4, 2018|work=Miami Herald|agency=Herald/Times Tallahassee Bureau|publisher=Miami Herald|date=January 3, 2018|location=Tallahassee, Florida}} The snowfall forced the closure of [[Savannah-Hilton Head International Airport]], cancelling 78 incoming and outgoing flights.{{cite news|last1=Shayanian|first1=Sara|last2=Haynes|first2=Danielle|title=Winter storm brings snow to Florida, closes southern airports|url=https://www.upi.com/Top_News/US/2018/01/03/Winter-storm-brings-snow-to-Florida-closes-southern-airports/6891514986523/|accessdate=January 4, 2018|agency=United Press International|publisher=United Press International, Inc.|date=January 3, 2018}} Ice accumulation was reported as far south as northern [[Levy County, Florida]].{{cite news|title=Winter Storm Grayson Southeast Recap: Snow and Ice From North Florida to the Eastern Carolinas|url=https://weather.com/storms/winter/news/2018-01-03-winter-storm-grayson-southeast-ice-snow-forecast|accessdate=January 5, 2018|agency=The Weather Channel|publisher=The Weather Company|date=January 4, 2018}} Widespread [[power outage]]s affected much of the Southeast U.S. coast during the storm's infancy; nearly 100,000 electricity customers were without power in the [[Florida]]-[[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]] border region,{{cite news|last1=Breslin|first1=Sean|title=Emergencies Declared in North Carolina, Virginia as Winter Storm Grayson Moves North|url=https://weather.com/news/news/2018-01-03-winter-storm-grayson-florida-georgia-carolinas-impacts-0|accessdate=January 4, 2018|agency=The Weather Channel|publisher=The Weather Company, LLC|date=January 3, 2018}} including over 6,000 in [[Glynn County, Georgia]]. Heavy icing downed trees and power lines throughout [[St. Simons, Georgia|St. Simons Island, Georgia]], causing extensive power outages.{{cite news|last1=Micolucci|first1=Vic|last2=Stacey|first2=Jonathan|title=Winter storm leaves thousands without power in NE Florida, SE Georgia|url=https://www.news4jax.com/news/winter-storm-leaving-thousands-without-power-in-ne-florida-se-georgia|accessdate=January 4, 2018|agency=News4Jax|publisher=News4Jax.com|date=January 3, 2018|location=Jacksonville, Florida}} Power outages impacted [[Nassau County, Florida]] to a similar extent, prompting the opening of an [[emergency shelter]] in [[Hilliard, Florida]].{{cite news|last1=Avanier|first1=Erik|title=Nassau County opens shelter due to power outages in Hilliard area|url=https://www.news4jax.com/news/florida/nassau-county/nassau-county-opening-shelter-due-power-outages-in-hilliard-area|accessdate=January 4, 2018|agency=News4Jax|publisher=News4Jax.com|date=January 3, 2018|location=Hilliard, Florida}} Other cold weather shelters throughout the area were opened by county officials, [[the Salvation Army]], and other [[non-governmental organization]]s.{{cite news|last1=Patrick|first1=Steve|title=Cold weather shelters open in Baker, Duval & Nassau counties|url=https://www.news4jax.com/news/local/jacksonville/cold-weather-shelters-open-baker-duval-nassau-counties|accessdate=January 4, 2018|agency=News4Jax|publisher=News4Jax.com|date=January 3, 2018|location=Jacksonville, Florida}} Four [[Central Florida]] counties also opened cold weather shelters.{{cite news|last1=Torralva|first1=Krista|title=Coldest air in years set to blast Florida|url=http://www.orlandosentinel.com/weather/os-florida-weather-freezing-20180102-story.html|accessdate=January 2, 2018|work=Orlando Sentinel|agency=Orlando Sentinel|publisher=Orlando Sentinel|location=Orlando, Florida}} Icy conditions forced numerous road closures, including an {{convert|80|mi|km|abbr=on}} stretch of [[Interstate 10]] between [[Tallahassee, Florida]] and [[Live Oak, Florida]]. All lanes of [[Interstate 75]] in [[Hamilton County, Florida]] to facilitate [[De-ice#Roadways|de-icing]].{{cite news|last1=Henning|first1=Allyson|last2=Harding|first2=Ashley|title=Snow, ice close some bridges in Georgia, I-10 reopens in Florida|url=https://www.news4jax.com/traffic/wintry-weather-closes-some-bridges-i-10-west-of-live-oak|accessdate=January 4, 2018|agency=News4Jax|publisher=News4Jax.com|date=January 3, 2018|location=Jacksonville, Florida}} [[File:Esb jan42018.jpg|alt=Empire State Building during a snow storm|thumb|right|175px|The [[Empire State Building]] barely visible from the 12th floor of an office building 2 blocks north during the peak of the storm due to near whiteout conditions.]] ====The Carolinas==== Snowfall in [[South Carolina]] peaked at {{convert|7.3|in|cm|abbr=on}} in [[Summerville, South Carolina|Summerville]]. [[Charleston, South Carolina|Charleston]] recorded the third highest daily snowfall total in its history at {{convert|5.3|in|cm|abbr=on}} and the highest total since 1989. The runways of [[Joint Base Charleston]], used jointly with [[Charleston International Airport]], were closed by the [[United States Air Force]]. A state of emergency was declared and a curfew enforced for much of [[Dorchester County, South Carolina|Dorchester County]].{{cite news|title=Dangerous travel conditions, power outages caused by snow and ice cripple coastal South Carolina|url=https://www.postandcourier.com/news/thousands-lose-power-travel-not-advised-as-snow-and-ice/article_fbca297a-f070-11e7-bdd2-5f83e31fbf0a.html|accessdate=January 4, 2018|work=The Post and Courier|agency=The Post and Courier|publisher=Post and Courier|date=January 3, 2018|location=Charleston, South Carolina}} On January 4, the [[South Carolina National Guard]] was deployed to assist impacted areas and the [[South Carolina Highway Patrol]] and [[South Carolina Department of Transportation]] to recover vehicles.{{cite news|last1=Krueger|first1=Nick|title=Gov. Henry McMaster authorizes SC National Guard resources for winter storm recovery|url=http://www.live5news.com/story/37192644/gov-henry-mcmaster-authorizes-sc-national-guard-resources-for-winter-storm-recovery|accessdate=January 5, 2018|work=Live 5 News|agency=WCSC-TV|publisher=Raycom Media|date=January 4, 2018|location=Charleston, South Carolina}} One person was killed in a traffic collision on [[Interstate 95]] in [[Clarendon County, South Carolina|Clarendon County]] due to icy road conditions following the storm's passage.{{cite news|last1=Jackson|first1=Angie|title=Some snow from historic winter storm turns to slush, but Lowcountry conditions remain icy and dicey|url=https://www.postandcourier.com/news/some-snow-from-historic-winter-storm-turns-to-slush-but/article_e406ebb6-f179-11e7-b729-0301b60aaa2b.html#tncms-source=article-nav-prev|accessdate=January 5, 2018|work=The Post and Courier|agency=The Post and Courier|publisher=Post and Courier|date=January 5, 2018|location=Charleston, South Carolina}} [[Governor of North Carolina]] [[Roy Cooper]] activated the state's emergency operations center on January 3 and declared a state of emergency for 54 counties.{{cite executive order| number = 2018-31| url = https://files.nc.gov/governor/documents/files/EO31%20-%20Declaration%20of%20a%20State%20of%20Emergency.pdf?avNr3R0YnMWc7DTlYty3gY40vxzECIjr| date = January 3, 2018| language = English| post = Governor of North Carolina| accessdate = January 4, 2018}} Due to the inclement conditions, 66 North Carolina school districts issued cancellations, affecting thousands of students. Local snowfalls in excess of {{convert|0.5|in|cm|abbr=on}} occurred across the eastern half of the state. [[Wilmington, North Carolina]] observed {{convert|3.8|in|cm|abbr=on}} of snowfall, marking the city's highest total since 2011. Along the [[Outer Banks]], gusts in excess of {{convert|70|mph|km/h|abbr=on}} caused rough seas, resulting in [[coastal flooding]]. Water levels rose {{convert|3|ft|m|abbr=on}} above normal in [[Buxton, North Carolina]]. Four people were killed in the state, including two each in [[Moore County, North Carolina|Moore]] and [[Beaufort County, North Carolina|Beaufort]] counties and one in [[Surf City, North Carolina|Surf City]]. At the height of the storm, around 20,000 utility customers lost power in the state.{{cite news|last1=Bonner|first1=Lynn|last2=Moody|first2=Aaron|title=Four dead in North Carolina after winter storm|url=http://www.newsobserver.com/news/weather/article192915414.html|accessdate=January 5, 2018|work=The News & Observer|agency=The News & Observer|publisher=Newsobserver.com|date=January 4, 2018|location=Raleigh, North Carolina}} Poor driving conditions resulted in around 900 vehicle crashes across North Carolina.{{cite news|last1=Waggoner|first1=Martha|last2=Drew|first2=Jonathan|title=Coastal North Carolina counties walloped by snow storm|url=http://www.houstonchronicle.com/news/article/Coastal-North-Carolina-counties-walloped-by-snow-12473833.php|accessdate=January 5, 2018|work=Houston Chronicle|agency=Associated Press|publisher=[[Hearst Newspapers, LLC]]|date=January 4, 2018|location=Raleigh, North Carolina}} ===Mid-Atlantic states=== [[File:Aftermath of the January snowfall in Newington.jpg|thumb|left|Aftermath of the blizzard in [[Newington, Virginia]].]] [[Governor of Virginia]] [[Terry McAuliffe]] declared a state of emergency in the state on January 3.{{cite press release |last=Coy|first=Brian|date=January 3, 2018|title=Governor McAuliffe Declares State of Emergency in Response to Impending Winter Storm|url=https://governor.virginia.gov/newsroom/newsarticle?articleId=22046|location=Richmond, Virginia|publisher=Commonwealth of Virginia|access-date=January 4, 2018}} In [[Virginia Beach, Virginia|Virginia Beach]], the storm maintained gusts of {{convert|50|-|55|mph|km/h|abbr=on}} for several hours. In one 24-hour period, 118 crashes occurred in the [[Hampton Roads]] area, with another 121 disabled vehicles reported.{{cite news|title=Icy roads will be major problem Thursday night into Friday|url=http://wavy.com/2018/01/04/winter-storm-local-travel-imapcts/|accessdate=January 5, 2018|agency=WAVY-TV|publisher=WAVY.com|date=January 4, 2018|location=Hampton Roads, Virginia}} Across the entirety of the state, Virginia troopers responded to 245 vehicular collisions.{{cite news|title=Winter storm results in 382 crashes, 409 disabled vehicle incidents in Va., Md. area|url=http://wjla.com/news/local/winter-storm-causes-277-crashes-226-disabled-vehicle-incidents-in-va-md|accessdate=January 5, 2018|agency=WJLA-TV|publisher=Sinclair Broadcast Group|date=January 4, 2018|location=Washington, D.C.}} Gusts in the Hampton Roads area peaked at {{convert|69|mph|km/h|abbr=on}} in [[Tangier, Virginia|Tangier]], with lesser gusts farther inland.{{cite news|title=Winter storm brings blizzard conditions to Hampton Roads|url=http://wavy.com/2018/01/04/winter-storm-coverage-january-2018/|accessdate=January 5, 2018|agency=WAVY-TV|publisher=WAVY.com|date=January 4, 2018|location=Hampton Roads, Virginia}} Due to the local geography, water levels in [[Chesapeake Bay]] fell in response to the storm's circulation passing to the east; the [[Patapsco River]] near [[Fort McHenry]] fell {{convert|3.49|ft|m|abbr=on}} below the mean low water level, reaching its lowest height since 1989.{{cite news|last1=Dance|first1=Scott|title=Baltimore records one of lowest tides in decades amid 'bomb cyclone' winds|url=http://www.baltimoresun.com/news/weather/weather-blog/bs-md-bomb-cyclone-tide-20180104-story.html|accessdate=January 5, 2018|work=The Baltimore Sun|agency=The Baltimore Sun|publisher=Baltimoresun.com|date=January 4, 2018|location=Baltimore, Maryland}} The [[United States Coast Guard]] restricted maritime access to the [[Port of Baltimore]] from the evening of January 3 into January 5.{{cite news|title=Coast Guard: No ships to enter Baltimore port ahead of storm|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/local/coast-guard-no-ships-to-enter-baltimore-port-ahead-of-storm/2018/01/03/820864e8-f102-11e7-95e3-eff284e71c8d_story.html|accessdate=January 5, 2018|work=The Washington Post|agency=Associated Press|publisher=The Washington Post|date=January 3, 2018|location=Baltimore, Maryland}} New York City encountered 30 mph winds, and [[John F. Kennedy International Airport|JFK Airport]] temporarily suspended flights due to [[Whiteout (weather)|whiteout]] conditions. [[Central Park]] reported {{convert|9.8|in}} of snow.{{cite web|last1=Samenow|first1=Jason|title=Historic ‘bomb cyclone’ unleashes blizzard conditions from coastal Virginia to New England. Frigid air to follow.|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/capital-weather-gang/wp/2018/01/04/historic-bomb-cyclone-unleashes-blizzard-conditions-from-coastal-virginia-to-new-england-frigid-air-to-follow/|website=The Washington Post|publisher=The Washington Post|accessdate=January 4, 2018}} [[Governor of New York]] [[Andrew Cuomo]] declared a state of emergency for [[Westchester County, New York|Westchester County]], New York City, and [[Long Island]].{{cite web|title=‘Bomb Cyclone’ Pummels Northeast, Whipping the East Coast With Snow and Bitter Cold|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/01/04/us/winter-snow-bomb-cyclone.html|website=The New York Times|publisher=The New York Times|accessdate=January 4, 2018}} [[File:Waves in Jeddore Harbour 2018-01-05.jpg|thumb|left|Waves breaking in [[Jeddore, Nova Scotia|Jeddore Harbour]] during the storm on January 5.]] New Jersey experienced as much as {{convert|17.0|in}} of snow in some places, with Islip on Long Island, NY reaching {{convert|16|in}} of snow; however, tropical storm-force winds blew the snow into banks as high as {{convert|3|ft}} in certain areas. ===New England=== Being the most geographically proximate to the storm's track, Massachusetts bore the highest impacts of all American states. Winds gusted to hurricane-force at {{convert|76|mph}} on [[Nantucket]] and over {{convert|70|mph}} on mainland Massachusetts.{{cite news|title=NWS Boston storm summary PNS|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180106041052/http://forecast.weather.gov/product.php?site=NWS&issuedby=BOX&product=PNS&format=txt&version=5&glossary=0|accessdate=January 5, 2018}} At least {{convert|17.0|in}} of snow fell on the [[Boston]] area, and {{convert|14.1|in}} fell in [[Providence, Rhode Island]]. In Boston, a storm tide of {{convert|15.16|ft|m|abbr=on}} was recorded during the blizzard which flooded areas of the financial district, including a [[Aquarium station (MBTA)|subway station]].{{cite news|title=‘Bomb Cyclone’ Pummels Northeast, Whipping the East Coast With Snow and Bitter Cold|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/01/04/us/winter-snow-bomb-cyclone.html|accessdate=January 4, 2018|work=The New York Times|agency=The New York Times|publisher=The New York Times Company|date=January 4, 2018|location=New York City, New York}} This beat the previous record set in 1978 by the [[Northeastern United States blizzard of 1978|Blizzard of 1978]].{{cite web|last1=Libon|first1=Daniel|title=Snowstorm Flooding Approaching Blizzard Of '78 Territory|url=https://patch.com/massachusetts/boston/snowstorm-approaching-blizzard-78-territory|website=Patch Staff|accessdate=January 4, 2018}} Significant coastal flooding occurred in [[Maine]] and [[New Hampshire]]. ===Atlantic Canada=== After ravaging New England, the storm moved on to [[Atlantic Canada]] on January 4 and 5. Heavy snow fell in New Brunswick, peaking at {{convert|60|cm}} in [[Bathurst, New Brunswick|Bathurst]]. [[Sydney, Nova Scotia|Sydney]] reported snowfall rates of up to 8 cm per hour, in heavy bands of [[thundersnow]]. While snowfall amounts closer to the Atlantic coast of Nova Scotia were very low, winds gusting up to {{convert|203|km/h|mph|abbr=on}} were reported in [[Saint-Joseph-du-Moine, Nova Scotia|Saint-Joseph-du-Moine]], causing widespread power outages. At the peak of the storm, nearly 130,000 [[Nova Scotia Power]] customers were left without power, while in [[New Brunswick]], around 19,000 [[NB Power]] customers were left without power. Offshore waves reached heights of {{convert|16|m|abbr=on}}.{{cite web|url=https://www.theweathernetwork.com/news/articles/winter-storm-wind-rain-snow-storm-surge-blizzard-east-atlantic-canada-maritimes-newfoundland-nova-scotia-pei/92924/|title=Hurricane force winds, 50+ cm of snow slams the Maritimes|first=Pelmorex Weather Networks|last=Inc.|website=The Weather Network|accessdate=January 5, 2018}} ===Bermuda=== On 5 January 2018, the storm was also responsible for a persistent thunderstorm that brought {{convert|1.84|in}} of rain and gale force winds to the island of [[Bermuda]]. However, due to the island’s latitude, no sub-zero temperatures were felt. There were wind gusts of up to {{convert|52|mph|km/h kn}}.{{cite web|author=Owain Johnston-Barnes |url=http://mobile.royalgazette.com/news/article/20180105/storm-grayson-blamed-for-poor-weather&template=mobileart |title=Storm Grayson blamed for poor weather | The Royal Gazette:Bermuda News - Mobile |publisher=Mobile.royalgazette.com |date=2018-01-05 |accessdate=2018-01-10}} ===Cruise ships=== On 4 January 2018, both the ''[[Norwegian Breakaway]]'' and the ''[[Norwegian Gem]]'' traveled through the storm causing major flooding in passenger staterooms. The ''Breakaway'', with 4,000 passengers, was sailing from [[the Bahamas]] back to [[New York City]] when it sustained flooding throughout the passenger cabins as well as elevators and the hallways. Some rooms were so badly flooded that some passengers slept in the public spaces. Footage of the ordeal showed the sides of the ship being hit by waves as high as {{convert|30|ft}}. At some points in the trip, the ship tilted so much that some passengers fell out of their beds. There was widespread damage to the interior as glasses fell out of shelves and some furniture toppled over. Paintings in the art gallery could be seen falling off the walls as the ship tilted to the shape of the waves. Seasickness was widespread as guests could be seen vomiting. While the Norwegian Cruise Line did formally apologize, some guests were traumatized to the point of refusing to cruise again. The incident has sparked outrage, with some customers threatening a class action lawsuit. The ship’s late arrival cut the following 14-day cruise short by one day.{{cite web|url=https://www.cbsnews.com/amp/news/norwegian-cruise-line-breakaway-passengers-bomb-cyclone-winter-storm-2018/?setDevice=amp |title="It was hell for me": Woman recalls cruise ship ride during "bomb cyclone" |publisher=CBS News |date= |accessdate=2018-01-10}}{{cite web|url=http://newyork.cbslocal.com/2018/01/05/cruise-through-storm/ |title=Norwegian Cruise Sailed Through Thick Of Winter Storm « CBS New York |publisher=Newyork.cbslocal.com |date=2018-01-05 |accessdate=2018-01-10}}{{cite web|url=http://www.foxnews.com/travel/2018/01/07/norwegian-cruise-line-passengers-on-ship-that-sailed-through-bomb-cyclone-describe-nightmare-ride.html |title=Norwegian Cruise Line passengers on ship that sailed through 'bomb cyclone' describe 'nightmare' ride |publisher=Fox News |date=2018-01-06 |accessdate=2018-01-10}} {{clear}} ==See also== {{commonscat|January 2018 North American blizzard}} {{portal|Weather}} *[[2017–18 North American cold wave]] – affected the United States at the same time *[[2017–18 North American winter]] *[[Early January 2014 nor'easter]] – similar system that impacted the Northeastern United States around the same time frame four years earlier *[[Early February 2013 North American blizzard]] – powerful blizzard that formed and took a track in a similar matter to the nor'easter. *[[March 2017 North American blizzard]] – significant winter storm that impacted much of the Northeastern United States nearly a year prior {{clr}} ==References== United States|Blizzard]] [[Category:2018 natural disasters in the United States]] [[Category:2018 disasters in Canada]] [[Category:2018 in Florida]] [[Category:2018 in Georgia (U.S. state)]] [[Category:2018 in Virginia]] [[Category:2018 in North Carolina]] [[Category:2018 in South Carolina]] [[Category:2018 in Washington, D.C.]] [[Category:2018 in Maryland]] [[Category:2018 in Pennsylvania]] [[Category:2018 in New Jersey]] [[Category:2018 in New York (state)]] [[Category:2018 in Massachusetts]] [[Category:2018 in Connecticut]] [[Category:2018 in Rhode Island]] revision.text:
[[File:Fred C Palmer freemason at Herne Bay.jpg|thumb|A young man in [[Herne Bay, Kent|Herne Bay]], Kent, England, around 1903 to 1914, showing hair groomed with Macassar oil]] '''Macassar oil''' is a compounded [[Vegetable fats and oils|oil]] used primarily by Western European men throughout the 1800s and early 1900s as a [[hair conditioner]] to groom and style the hair.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.detailsformen.com/Articles_Detail.aspx?PCID=35 |title=Men's Hair Care Lesson: How Conditioner Works |publisher=Detailsformen.com |date= |accessdate=2014-06-22 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20141006095312/https://www.detailsformen.com/Articles_Detail.aspx?PCID=35 |archivedate=2014-10-06 |df= }}</ref>
It was popularised by Alexander Rowland (1747-1823), a celebrated London barber. It was then not uncommon for barbers to make their own hair preparations, and around 1783 Rowland began offering Rowland's Macassar Oil. Within two decades it had become hugely popular, and was aggressively advertised with extravagant claims of its effectiveness, becoming one of the first nationally advertised products.
The words ''Macassar Oil'' were registered as a trademark by A. Rowland & Sons, in 1888. Rowland's son (also named Alexander) later stated that a relative living in the island of [[Celebes]] in the [[Dutch East Indies]] had helped in procurement of the basic ingredient.
Macassar oil is often made with [[coconut oil]] or [[palm oil]] or that of ''[[Schleichera oleosa]]'',<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Ghosh |first1=P |last2=Chakraborty |first2=P |last3=Mandal |first3=A |last4=Rasul |first4=M G |last5=Chakraborty |first5=Madhumita |last6=Saha |first6=A |title=Triterpenoids from ''Schleichera oleosa'' of Darjeeling Foothills and Their Antimicrobial Activity |journal=Indian Journal of Pharmaceutical Sciences |date=Mar–Apr 2011 |volume=73 |issue=2 |pages=231–233 |pmc=3267311 |pmid=22303070 |doi=10.4103/0250-474x.91568}}</ref> combined with [[ylang-ylang]] oil (obtained by processing the flowers of the ylang-ylang tree, ''Cananga odorata'') and other fragrant oils.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.essentialoils.co.za/essential-oils/ylang-ylang.htm |title=Ylang-ylang essential oil information |publisher=Essentialoils.co.za |date=2014-05-29 |accessdate=2014-06-22}}</ref>
Macassar oil was so named because it was reputed to have been manufactured from ingredients purchased in the port of [[Makassar]] in the [[Dutch East Indies]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.abc.net.au/abc3/myplace/narrowband/1798/oil.htm |title=Macassar Oil |publisher=Abc.net.au |date= |accessdate=2014-06-22}}</ref> The poet [[George Gordon, Lord Byron|Byron]] facetiously called it "thine incomparable oil, Macassar" in the first canto of ''[[Don Juan (Byron)|Don Juan]]'', and [[Lewis Carroll]] also mentions "Rowland's Macassar Oil" in the poem "[[Haddocks' Eyes]]" from ''[[Through the Looking-Glass]]''. [[File:An obese bald-headed old man seated in an armchair while a s Wellcome V0019909.jpg|thumb|Illustration by [[Thomas Rowlandson]] from around 1814 making fun of the false claim in some advertisements that Macassar oil would stimulate hair growth on balding men. ]] Due to the tendency for the oil to transfer from the user's hair to the back of his chair, the [[antimacassar]] was developed. This is a small cloth ([[crochet]]ed, embroidered or mass-produced), placed over the back of a chair to protect the upholstery.<ref>[[Charles Dickens]], ''[[Sketches by Boz]]'' 1836: Tales: Ch 4, The Tuggses at Ramsgate</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.fragrantica.com/notes/Ylang-Ylang-24.html Ylang-Ylang] *[http://www.vintagerecipes.net/books/whitehouse/macassar_oil_for_the_hair.php Macassar Oil for the Hair]
[[Category:Hairdressing]]
{{Fashion-stub}} {{material-stub}}

revision.text:
[[File:Marine-loading-arm.jpg|thumb|right|One of three marine loading arms connects this [[oil tanker]] to the pier.|239x239px]] [[File:JLA Marine Loading Arms.jpg|thumb|One of two marine loading arms connected to an [[oil tanker]] by Dutch company [http://www.jla-loadingarms.com/ JLA Loading Technology].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.jla-loadingarms.com/|title=Marine Loading Arms|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>|340x340px]] A '''marine loading arm''', also known as a '''mechanical loading arm''', '''loading arm''', or '''MLA''' is a [[mechanical arm]] consisting of articulated steel pipes that connect a [[tankship]] such as an [[oil tanker]] or [[chemical tanker]] to a cargo terminal. [[Genericized trademark]]s such as '''Chiksan''' (often misspelled '''Chicksan''') are often used to refer to marine loading arms.<ref name="h83">Huber, 2001, p.83.</ref><ref name="hkg7">Hayler and Keever, 2001, p. G-7.</ref>
==Operation and design== A marine [[loading arm]] is an alternative to direct hose hookups that is particularly useful for larger vessels and transfers at higher loading rates and pressures.<ref name="h83"/> Controlled manually or hydraulically, a loading arm employs swivel joints and can, to some extent, follow the movement of a moored vessel.<ref name="h83"/><ref name="hk1410">Hayler and Keever, 2001, p. 14-10 to 14-11.</ref> Many loading arm systems feature quick-connect fittings.<ref name="h83"/> [[Gasket]] or [[o-ring]] arrangements are required to make a secure seal to the ship's manifold flange.<ref name="h83"/> A loading arm must be drained or closed off before the connection is broken off.<ref name="h84">Huber, 2001, p.84.</ref> This is usually done in two ways. For fuels such as gas oil and diesel, the lines can be blown out with high pressure air. In the case of fuels such as kerosene or petrol, the lines can be stripped with pumps.
Loading arms can handle both liquids and gases, in a wide range of viscosities and temperatures.<ref name="fmcchik"/> Cargoes from [[liquid sulphur]] to [[liquefied natural gas]] are moved through marine loading arms.<ref name="fmcchik"/> Loading arms service vessels in a wide range of sizes, from small [[river barges]] to the largest [[supertanker]]s.<ref name="fmcchik"/>
Various designs exist, and specific installations can be tailored for a given port based on considerations such as vessel size, cargo flow rate and cargo temperature.<ref name="fmcchik"/> Environmental constraints, such as the range of tide, wind conditions, and earthquake tolerance, can also affect choice of loading arm.<ref name="fmcchik">FMC Technologies, 2005, ''Chiksan Marine Loading Arms''.</ref> A loading arm installation may include add-ons such as hydraulic or manual quick connect couplers, position monitoring systems, emergency release systems, and piggyback vapor return lines.<ref name="fmcchik"/>
Compared to cargo hoses, the loading arm's main drawback is its comparative lack of flexibility.<ref name="h83"/>
==History== [[File:Chassiron main deck.jpg|thumb|right|A [[Chemical tanker|chemical]] or [[oil tanker]] connected to the pier with a marine loading arm.]]Since the earliest days of tankships, the need to safely and efficiently transfer bulk liquid to a moored ship has been fundamental. An insufficient solution to this problem led to one of the world's first oil tanker disasters.<ref name="to55">Tolf, 1976, p. 55.</ref> In 1881, the [[Branobel]] tanker ''Nordenskjöld'' was taking on [[kerosene]] in [[Baku]].<ref name="to55"/> The ship was connected to the pier with a simple piece of pipe.<ref name="to55"/> While loading, the ship was hit by a gust of wind and the cargo pipe carrying was jerked away from the hold.<ref name="to55"/> Kerosene then spilled onto the deck and down into the engine room, where mechanics were working in the light of kerosene lanterns.<ref name="to55"/> The ship then exploded, killing half the crew.<ref name="to55"/> [[Ludvig Nobel]] responded to the disaster by creating a flexible, leakproof loading pipe which was much more resistant to spills.<ref name="to56">Tolf, 1976, p. 56.</ref>
Chiksan brand marine loading arm manufacturer [[FMC Technologies]] claims to have built the world's first all-steel marine loading arm in 1956 and to have over 8,000 units installed worldwide.<ref name="fmcabout">FMC Technologies, 2005, ''About Us''.</ref>
==See also== {{Portal|Nautical}} *[[Oil tanker]] *[[Chemical tanker]]
==Notes== {{Reflist}}

Loading Equipment website |publisher=KANON Loading Equipment}} *{{cite web|url=http://www.jla-loadingarms.com/about-jla|title=JLA Loading Arms|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|accessdate=|author=JLA Loading Arms|first=|authorlink=JLA Loading Arms|date=|year=2013|work=JLA Loading Arms website|publisher=JLA Loading Arms}} *{{cite web 0-87033-549-9 }} *{{cite book |first=Mark| last=Huber |title=Tanker operations: a handbook for the person-in-charge (PIC) |publisher=Cornell Maritime Press |location=Cambridge, MD |year=2001 |pages= |isbn=0-87033-528-6 |oclc= |doi=}} *{{cite book |author=International Chamber of Shipping |title=International Safety Guide for Oil Tankers and Terminals (ISGOTT) |publisher=Hyperion Books Family and the Russian Oil Industry |origdate= |origyear=|origmonth= |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=3DmsQLtWq1wC |format= |accessdate= |edition= |series= |volume= |year=1976 |publisher=Hoover Press |location= |language= |isbn=0-8179-6581-5 |oclc= |doi= |id= |pages= |chapter=4: The World's First Oil Tankers |chapterurl=https://books.google.com/books?id=3DmsQLtWq1wC&pg=PR38&dq=%2BNobel+%2Btanker+%2BZoroaster&num=100&sig=CpA2y3iTadVv_iihDA5mp_sN92M#PPA50,M1 |quote= }} * {{cite book | last = Turpin | first edition = 4th | series = | year = 1980 | publisher =Cornell Maritime Press | location = Centreville, MD | language = | isbn = 0-87033-056-X | oclc = | doi = | id = | pages = | chapter = | chapterurl = | quote = }}

revision.text:
'''Miedema's model''' is a semi-empirical approach for estimating the heat of formation of solid or [[liquid metal]] alloys and /or compounds in the framework of thermodynamic calculations for metals and minerals.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://digicoll.manoa.hawaii.edu/techreports/PDF/USBM-677.pdf|title=Thermodynamic Data for Mineral Technology|last=|first=|date=1984|access-date=27 November 2017}}</ref> It was developed by the Dutch scientist Andries Rinse Miedema ( 15 November 1933 - 28 May 1992 <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dwc.knaw.nl/DL/levensberichten/PE00001893.pdf |format=PDF |title=Huygens Institute - Royal Netherlands Academy of Arts and Sciences (KNAW) : Q.H.F. Vrehen, Levensbericht A.R. Miedema, in: Levensberichten en herdenkingen, 1993, Amsterdam |pages=61–66 |website=Dwc.knaw.nl |accessdate=2017-02-28}}</ref> ) while working at Philips Research Laboratories [[Philips_Natuurkundig_Laboratorium]]. It may provide or confirm basic enthalpy data that have always been needed for the calculation of [[phase diagram]]s of metals, and that are now currently approached by [[CALPHAD]]. The method has been introduced by Miedema in a couple of papers appeared in 1973 in Philips Technical Review Magazine entitled "A simple model for alloys".<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Miedema|first=A.R.|year=1973|title=A simple model for alloys. I. Rules for the alloying behaviour of transition metals|url=http://www.extra.research.philips.com/hera/people/aarts/_Philips%20Bound%20Archive/PTechReview/PTechReview-33-1973-149.pdf|journal=Philips Technical Review|volume=33|pages=149–160|via=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Miedema|first=A.R.|year=1973|title=A simple model for alloys. Il, The influence of ionicity on the stability and other physical properties of alloys|url=http://www.extra.research.philips.com/hera/people/aarts/_Philips%20Bound%20Archive/PTechReview/PTechReview-33-1973-196.pdf|journal=Philips Technical Review|volume=33|pages=196–202|via=}}</ref> While Miedema himself or with collaborators produced many scientific papers we report here in his own words the genuine motivation of his approach "Reliable rules for the alloying behaviour of metals have long been sought. There is the qualitative rule that states that the greater the difference in the electronegativity of two metals, the greater the heat of formation - and hence the stability. Then there is the [[Hume-Rothery rules|Hume-Rothery rule]], which states that two metals that differ by more than 15% in their atomic radius will not form substitutional solid solutions. This rule can only be used reliably (90 % success) to predict poor solubility; it cannot predict good solubility. The author has proposed a simple atomic model, which is empirical like the other two rules, but nevertheless has a clear physical basis and predicts the alloying behaviour of transition metals accurately in 98 % of cases. The model is very suitable for graphical presentation of the data and is therefore easy to use in practice." There are several free web bases applications like Entall <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.entall.imim.pl/calculator/ |title=Miedema calculator of standard formation enthalpy |website=Entall.imim.pl |date= |accessdate=2017-02-28}}</ref> or Miedema Calculator.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://zrftum.wordpress.com/ |title=Welcome to >>> Miedema Calculator | Homepage organized by Dr. Zhang |website=Zrftum.wordpress.com |date= |accessdate=2017-02-28}}</ref> The latter has been recently reviewed and improved, with an extension of the method in a scientific publication.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/j.cpc.2016.08.013 |title=Miedema Calculator: A thermodynamic platform for predicting formation enthalpies of alloys within framework of Miedema's Theory |journal=Computer Physics Communications |volume=209 |pages=58–69 |year=2016 |last1=Zhang |first1=R.F. |last2=Zhang |first2=S.H. |last3=He |first3=Z.J. |last4=Jing |first4=J. |last5=Sheng |first5=S.H. |bibcode=2016CoPhC.209...58Z }}</ref> A simple presentation of the method is in the appendix B of the book,<ref>{{cite book |first=N. A. |last=Gokcen |year=1986 |chapter=Appendix B |pages=255–76 |chapterurl=https://link.springer.com/content/pdf/bbm%3A978-1-4684-5053-8%2F1.pdf |title=Statistical Thermodynamics of Alloys |isbn=978-1-4684-5053-8 }}</ref> while the original Algol program <ref>{{Cite journal|last=A.K. Niessen, F.R. de Boer, R. Boom, P.F. de Châtel, W.C.M. Mattens, A.R. Miedema|first=|year=1983|title=Model predictions for the enthalpy of formation of transition metal alloys II|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/0364591683900305|journal=Calphad|volume= 7| issue = 1, January–March|pages=Pages 51–70|via=Elsevier Science Direct}}</ref> has been ported in a fortran code <ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.emresururi.com/physics/?p=81|title=Hex, Bugs and More Physics {{!}} Emre S. Tasci » Blog Archive » Miedema et al.’s Enthalpy code — 25 years after..|website=www.emresururi.com|access-date=2017-03-04}}</ref>
==Implication of Miedema's model on an informatics guided classification of miscible and immiscible binary alloy systems==
A recent open journal work <ref>{{Cite journal|last=Zhang |first=R.F.|year=2017|title=An informatics guided classification of miscible and immiscible binary alloy systems |url=https://www.nature.com/articles/s41598-017-09704-1.pdf |journal=Scientific Reports Volume 77, Issue 1, 1 December 2017}}</ref> emphasizes the capabilities of Miedema's approach in the classification of miscible and immiscible systems of binary alloys. These are extremely relevant in the design of multicomponent alloys. The paper by mining data from hundreds of experimental phase diagrams, and thousands of thermodynamic data sets from experiments and high-throughput first-principles (HTFP) calculations, obtains a comprehensive classification of alloying behavior for 813 binary alloy systems consisting of transition and lanthanide metals. "Impressively, the classification by the miscibility map yields a robust validation on the capability of the well-known Miedema’s theory (95% agreement) and shows good agreement with the HTFP method (90% agreement). These 2017 results demonstrate that "a state-of-the art physics-guided data mining can provide an efficient pathway for knowledge discovery in the next generation of materials design". See also the html version of the paper by Zhang, R.F., Kong, X.F., Wang, H.T., Zhang, S.H., Legut, D., Sheng, S.H., Srinivasan, S., Rajan, K., Germann, T.C. [https://www.nature.com/articles/s41598-017-09704-1#Sec12]

revision.text:
{{Redirect2|Molecules|Molecular||Molecules (journal)|and|Molecular (game)}} {{pp-move-indef}} {{Use dmy dates|date=February 2016}} [[File:PTCDA AFM.jpg|thumb|[[Atomic force microscopy]] (AFM) image of a [[Perylenetetracarboxylic dianhydride|PTCDA]] molecule, in which the five six-carbon rings are visible.<ref>{{cite journal|doi=10.1038/ncomms8766|pmid=26178193|pmc=4518281|title=Chemical structure imaging of a single molecule by atomic force microscopy at room temperature|journal=Nature Communications|volume=6|page=7766|year=2015|last1=Iwata|first1=Kota|last2=Yamazaki|first2=Shiro|last3=Mutombo|first3=Pingo|last4=Hapala|first4=Prokop|last5=Ondráček|first5=Martin|last6=Jelínek|first6=Pavel|last7=Sugimoto|first7=Yoshiaki|bibcode= 2015NatCo...6E7766I}}</ref>]] [[File:Pentacene on Ni(111) STM.jpg|thumb|A [[scanning tunneling microscopy]] image of [[pentacene]] molecules, which consist of linear chains of five carbon rings.<ref>{{cite journal|doi=10.1039/C4NR07057G|pmid=25619890|title=Pentacene on Ni(111): Room-temperature molecular packing and temperature-activated conversion to graphene|journal=Nanoscale|volume=7|issue=7|pages=3263–9|year=2015|last1=Dinca|first1=L. E.|last2=De Marchi|first2=F.|last3=MacLeod|first3=J. M.|last4=Lipton-Duffin|first4=J.|last5=Gatti|first5=R.|last6=Ma|first6=D.|last7=Perepichka|first7=D. F.|last8=Rosei|first8=F.|bibcode= 2015Nanos...7.3263D}}</ref>]] [[File:TOAT AFM.png|thumb|AFM image of 1,5,9-trioxo-13-azatriangulene and its chemical structure.<ref>{{cite journal|doi=10.1038/ncomms11560|pmid=27230940|pmc=4894979|title=Mapping the electrostatic force field of single molecules from high-resolution scanning probe images|journal=Nature Communications|volume=7|pages=11560|year=2016|last1=Hapala|first1=Prokop|last2=Švec|first2=Martin|last3=Stetsovych|first3=Oleksandr|last4=Van Der Heijden|first4=Nadine J.|last5=Ondráček|first5=Martin|last6=Van Der Lit|first6=Joost|last7=Mutombo|first7=Pingo|last8=Swart|first8=Ingmar|last9=Jelínek|first9=Pavel|bibcode=2016NatCo...711560H}}</ref>]]
A '''molecule''' is an [[electrically]] neutral group of two or more [[atom]]s held together by [[chemical bond]]s.<ref name="iupac">{{GoldBookRef| title=Molecule|file=M04002|accessdate=23 February 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite book| author= Ebbin, Darrell D.| title= General Chemistry |edition=3rd| date= 1990| publisher= [[Houghton Mifflin Co.]]| location= Boston| isbn= 0-395-43302-9}}</ref><ref>{{cite book| author= Brown, T.L. |author2=Kenneth C. Kemp |author3=Theodore L. Brown |author4=Harold Eugene LeMay |author5=Bruce Edward Bursten |title= Chemistry – the Central Science |edition=9th| date= 2003| publisher= [[Prentice Hall]]| location= New Jersey| isbn= 0-13-066997-0}}</ref><ref>{{cite book| last= Chang| first= Raymond| title= Chemistry |edition=6th| date= 1998| publisher= [[McGraw Hill]]| location= New York| isbn= 0-07-115221-0}}</ref><ref>{{cite book| author= Zumdahl, Steven S.| title= Chemistry |edition=4th| date= 1997| publisher= Houghton Mifflin| location= Boston| isbn= 0-669-41794-7}}</ref> Molecules are distinguished from [[ion]]s by their lack of [[electrical charge]]. However, in [[quantum physics]], [[organic chemistry]], and [[biochemistry]], the term ''molecule'' is often used less strictly, also being applied to [[polyatomic ion]]s.
In the [[kinetic theory of gases]], the term ''molecule'' is often used for any gaseous [[particle]] regardless of its composition. According to this definition, [[noble gas]] atoms are considered molecules as they are monatomic molecules.<ref>{{cite book| last= Chandra| first= Sulekh| title= Comprehensive Inorganic Chemistry| date= 2005| publisher= New Age Publishers| isbn= 81-224-1512-1}}</ref>
A molecule may be [[homonuclear]], that is, it consists of atoms of one [[chemical element]], as with [[oxygen]] (O<sub>2</sub>); or it may be [[heteronuclear]], a [[chemical compound]] composed of more than one element, as with [[water (molecule)|water]] (H<sub>2</sub>O). Atoms and complexes connected by [[non-covalent interactions]], such as [[hydrogen bond]]s or [[ionic bond]]s, are generally not considered single molecules.<ref>{{cite encyclopedia|title= Molecule|encyclopedia=[[Encyclopædia Britannica]]|date =22 January 2016|url=http://global.britannica.com/science/molecule|access-date=23 February 2016}}</ref>
Molecules as components of matter are common in organic substances (and therefore biochemistry). They also make up most of the oceans and atmosphere. However, the majority of familiar solid substances on Earth, including most of the minerals that make up the [[Crust (geology)|crust]], [[Mantle (geology)|mantle]], and [[Earth core|core of the Earth]], contain many chemical bonds, but are ''not'' made of identifiable molecules. Also, no typical molecule can be defined for [[ionic crystal]]s ([[salt (chemistry)|salts]]) and covalent crystals ([[network solid]]s), although these are often composed of repeating [[unit cell]]s that extend either in a [[Plane (mathematics)|plane]] (such as in [[graphene]]) or three-dimensionally (such as in [[diamond]], [[quartz]], or [[sodium chloride]]). The theme of repeated unit-cellular-structure also holds for most condensed phases with [[metallic bond]]ing, which means that solid metals are also not made of molecules. In [[glass]]es (solids that exist in a vitreous disordered state), atoms may also be held together by chemical bonds with no presence of any definable molecule, nor any of the regularity of repeating units that characterizes crystals.
== Molecular science ==
The science of molecules is called ''molecular chemistry'' or ''[[molecular physics]]'', depending on whether the focus is on chemistry or physics. Molecular chemistry deals with the laws governing the interaction between molecules that results in the formation and breakage of [[chemical bond]]s, while molecular physics deals with the laws governing their structure and properties. In practice, however, this distinction is vague. In molecular sciences, a molecule consists of a stable system ([[bound state]]) composed of two or more [[atom]]s. [[Polyatomic ion]]s may sometimes be usefully thought of as electrically charged molecules. The term ''unstable molecule'' is used for very [[reactivity (chemistry)|reactive]] species, i.e., short-lived assemblies ([[Resonance (chemistry)|resonances]]) of electrons and [[atomic nucleus|nuclei]], such as [[radical (chemistry)|radicals]], molecular [[ion]]s, [[Rydberg molecule]]s, [[transition state]]s, [[van der Waals bonding|van der Waals complexes]], or systems of colliding atoms as in [[Bose–Einstein condensate]].
== History and etymology == {{Main|History of molecular theory}}
According to [[Merriam-Webster]] and the [[Online Etymology Dictionary]], the word "molecule" derives from the [[Latin]] "[[Mole (unit)|moles]]" or small unit of mass. * '''Molecule''' (1794) – "extremely minute particle", from French ''{{linktext|molécule}}'' (1678), from [[New Latin]] ''{{linktext|molecula}}'', diminutive of Latin ''{{linktext|moles}}'' "mass, barrier". A vague meaning at first; the vogue for the word (used until the late 18th century only in Latin form) can be traced to the philosophy of [[René Descartes|Descartes]].<ref>{{OEtymD|molecule|accessdate=2016-02-22}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=molecule|url=http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/molecule|publisher=[[Merriam-Webster]]|accessdate=22 February 2016}}</ref>
The definition of the molecule has evolved as knowledge of the structure of molecules has increased. Earlier definitions were less precise, defining molecules as the smallest [[list of particles#Molecules|particles]] of pure [[chemical substance]]s that still retain their [[chemical compound|composition]] and chemical properties.<ref>[http://antoine.frostburg.edu/chem/senese/101/glossary/m.shtml#molecule Molecule Definition] ([[Frostburg State University]])</ref> This definition often breaks down since many substances in ordinary experience, such as [[rock (geology)|rocks]], [[salt (chemistry)|salts]], and [[metal]]s, are composed of large crystalline networks of [[chemical bond|chemically bonded]] atoms or [[ion]]s, but are not made of discrete molecules. {{clear}}
== Bonding ==
Molecules are held together by either [[covalent bonding]] or [[ionic bonding]]. Several types of non-metal elements exist only as molecules in the environment. For example, hydrogen only exists as hydrogen molecule. A molecule of a compound is made out of two or more elements.<ref>{{cite web|title=The Hutchinson unabridged encyclopedia with atlas and weather guide|url=http://www.worldcat.org/title/hutchinson-unabridged-encyclopedia-with-atlas-and-weather-guide/oclc/696918830|website=worldcat.org|publisher=Oxford, England|accessdate=28 February 2016}}</ref>
=== Covalent === {{main|Covalent bonding}} [[File:Covalent bond hydrogen.svg|thumb|right|A covalent bond forming H<sub>2</sub> (right) where two [[hydrogen atom]]s share the two electrons]] A covalent bond is a [[chemical bond]] that involves the sharing of [[electron pair]]s between [[atom]]s. These electron pairs are termed ''shared pairs'' or ''bonding pairs'', and the stable balance of attractive and repulsive forces between atoms, when they share electrons, is termed ''covalent bonding''.<ref>{{cite book| author2= Brad Williamson; Robin J. Heyden| last= Campbell| first= Neil A.| title= Biology: Exploring Life| url= http://www.phschool.com/el_marketing.html| accessdate= 2012-02-05| year= 2006| publisher= [[Pearson Prentice Hall]]| location= Boston, Massachusetts| isbn= 0-13-250882-6}}</ref> {{clear}}
=== Ionic === {{main|Ionic bonding}} [[File:NaF.gif|thumb|left|[[Sodium]] and [[fluorine]] undergoing a redox reaction to form [[sodium fluoride]]. Sodium loses its outer [[electron]] to give it a stable [[electron configuration]], and this electron enters the fluorine atom [[exothermic]]ally.]]
Ionic bonding is a type of [[chemical bond]] that involves the [[electrostatic]] attraction between oppositely charged [[ion]]s, and is the primary interaction occurring in [[ionic compound]]s. The ions are atoms that have lost one or more [[electron]]s (termed [[cation]]s) and atoms that have gained one or more electrons (termed [[anion]]s).<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=6VdROgeQ5M8C&pg=PA7&dq=ionic+bonding+-wikipedia&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwi34bOG_6nTAhVnl1QKHRLZBeoQ6AEILTAC#v=onepage&q=ionic%20bonding%20-wikipedia&f=false|title=Elements of Metallurgy and Engineering Alloys|last=Campbell|first=Flake C.|date=2008-01-01|publisher=[[ASM International]]|isbn=9781615030583|language=en}}</ref> This transfer of electrons is termed ''electrovalence'' in contrast to [[covalent bond|covalence]]. In the simplest case, the cation is a [[metal]] atom and the anion is a [[nonmetal]] atom, but these ions can be of a more complicated nature, e.g. molecular ions like NH<sub>4</sub><sup>+</sup> or SO<sub>4</sub><sup>2−</sup>. Basically, an ionic bond is the transfer of electrons from a metal to a non-metal for both atoms to obtain a full valence shell. {{clear}}
== Molecular size ==
Most molecules are far too small to be seen with the naked eye, but there are exceptions. [[DNA]], a [[macromolecule]], can reach [[macroscopic]] sizes, as can molecules of many [[polymer]]s. Molecules commonly used as building blocks for organic synthesis have a dimension of a few [[angstrom]]s (Å) to several dozen Å, or around one billionth of a meter. Single molecules cannot usually be observed by [[light]] (as noted above), but small molecules and even the outlines of individual atoms may be traced in some circumstances by use of an [[atomic force microscope]]. Some of the largest molecules are [[macromolecule]]s or [[supermolecule]]s.
The smallest molecule is the [[diatomic]] [[hydrogen]] (H<sub>2</sub>), with a bond length of 0.74 Å.<ref>{{cite book| author= Roger L. DeKock |author2=Harry B. Gray|author3=Harry B. Gray| title= Chemical structure and bonding| url= https://books.google.com/?id=q77rPHP5fWMC&pg=PA199| date= 1989| publisher= University Science Books| isbn= 0-935702-61-X| page= 199}}</ref>
Effective molecular radius is the size a molecule displays in solution.<ref>{{cite journal |author=Chang RL |author2=Deen WM |author3=Robertson CR |author4=Brenner BM |title=Permselectivity of the glomerular capillary wall: III. Restricted transport of polyanions |journal=Kidney Int. |volume=8 |issue=4 |pages=212–218 |year=1975 |pmid=1202253 |doi=10.1038/ki.1975.104 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |author=Chang RL |author2=Ueki IF |author3=Troy JL |author4=Deen WM |author5=Robertson CR |author6=Brenner BM |title=Permselectivity of the glomerular capillary wall to macromolecules. II. Experimental studies in rats using neutral dextran |journal=Biophys. J. |volume=15 |issue=9 |pages=887–906 |year=1975 |pmid=1182263 |doi=10.1016/S0006-3495(75)85863-2 |pmc=1334749 |bibcode= 1975BpJ....15..887C}}</ref> The [[table of permselectivity for different substances]] contains examples.
== Molecular formulas ==
=== Chemical formula types === {{Main|Chemical formula}}
The [[chemical formula]] for a molecule uses one line of [[chemical element]] symbols, numbers, and sometimes also other symbols, such as parentheses, dashes, brackets, and ''plus'' (+) and ''minus'' (−) signs. These are limited to one typographic line of symbols, which may include subscripts and superscripts.
A compound's [[empirical formula]] is a very simple type of chemical formula.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=6wUmteTIc18C&pg=PA288&dq=empirical+formula&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiv64bBh6rTAhUSwmMKHb3vB0IQ6AEIOjAF#v=onepage&q=empirical%20formula&f=false|title=The Practice of Chemistry|last=Wink|first=Donald J.|last2=Fetzer-Gislason|first2=Sharon|last3=McNicholas|first3=Sheila|date=2003-03-01|publisher=Macmillan|isbn=9780716748717|language=en}}</ref> It is the simplest [[integer]] [[ratio]] of the [[chemical element]]s that constitute it.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.chemteam.info/Mole/EmpiricalFormula.html|title=ChemTeam: Empirical Formula|website=www.chemteam.info|access-date=2017-04-16}}</ref> For example, water is always composed of a 2:1 ratio of [[hydrogen]] to [[oxygen]] atoms, and ethyl [[alcohol]] or [[ethanol]] is always composed of [[carbon]], [[hydrogen]], and [[oxygen]] in a 2:6:1 ratio. However, this does not determine the kind of molecule uniquely – [[dimethyl ether]] has the same ratios as ethanol, for instance. Molecules with the same [[atom]]s in different arrangements are called [[isomer]]s. Also carbohydrates, for example, have the same ratio (carbon:hydrogen:oxygen= 1:2:1) (and thus the same empirical formula) but different total numbers of atoms in the molecule.
The [[molecular formula]] reflects the exact number of atoms that compose the molecule and so characterizes different molecules. However different isomers can have the same atomic composition while being different molecules.
The empirical formula is often the same as the molecular formula but not always. For example, the molecule [[acetylene]] has molecular formula C<sub>2</sub>H<sub>2</sub>, but the simplest integer ratio of elements is CH.
The [[molecular mass]] can be calculated from the [[chemical formula]] and is expressed in conventional [[atomic mass unit]]s equal to 1/12 of the mass of a neutral carbon-12 (<sup>12</sup>[[carbon|C]] [[isotope]]) atom. For [[network solid]]s, the term [[formula unit]] is used in [[stoichiometric]] calculations. {{clear}}
=== Structural formula === {{Main|Structural formula}}
[[File:Atisane3.png|thumb|right|upright=1.8|[[Three-dimensional space|3D]] (left and center) and [[2D geometric model|2D]] (right) representations of the [[terpenoid]] molecule atisane]]
For molecules with a complicated 3-dimensional structure, especially involving atoms bonded to four different substituents, a simple molecular formula or even semi-structural [[chemical formula]] may not be enough to completely specify the molecule. In this case, a graphical type of formula called a [[structural formula]] may be needed. Structural formulas may in turn be represented with a one-dimensional chemical name, but such [[chemical nomenclature]] requires many words and terms which are not part of chemical formulas. {{clear}}
== Molecular geometry == {{Main|Molecular geometry}}
[[File:Cyanostar STM.png|thumb|left|upright|Structure and [[Scanning tunneling microscopy|STM]] image of a "cyanostar" [[dendrimer]] molecule.<ref>{{cite journal|doi=10.1039/C4CC03725A|pmid=25080328|title=Anion-induced dimerization of 5-fold symmetric cyanostars in 3D crystalline solids and 2D self-assembled crystals|journal=Chemical Communications|volume=50|issue=69|pages=9827–30|year=2014|last1=Hirsch|first1=Brandon E.|last2=Lee|first2=Semin|last3=Qiao|first3=Bo|last4=Chen|first4=Chun-Hsing|last5=McDonald|first5=Kevin P.|last6=Tait|first6=Steven L.|last7=Flood|first7=Amar H.}}</ref>]]
Molecules have fixed [[mechanical equilibrium|equilibrium]] geometries—bond lengths and angles— about which they continuously oscillate through vibrational and rotational motions. A pure substance is composed of molecules with the same average geometrical structure. The chemical formula and the structure of a molecule are the two important factors that determine its properties, particularly its [[reactivity (chemistry)|reactivity]]. [[Isomers]] share a chemical formula but normally have very different properties because of their different structures. [[Stereoisomer]]s, a particular type of isomer, may have very similar physico-chemical properties and at the same time different [[biochemistry|biochemical]] activities.
== Molecular spectroscopy == {{Main|Spectroscopy}}
[[File:Dehydrogenation of H2TPP by STM.jpg|thumb|upright=1.3|Hydrogen can be removed from individual [[Tetraphenylporphyrin|H<sub>2</sub>TPP]] molecules by applying excess voltage to the tip of a [[scanning tunneling microscope]] (STM, a); this removal alters the current-voltage (I-V) curves of TPP molecules, measured using the same STM tip, from [[diode]] like (red curve in b) to [[resistor]] like (green curve). Image (c) shows a row of TPP, H<sub>2</sub>TPP and TPP molecules. While scanning image (d), excess voltage was applied to H<sub>2</sub>TPP at the black dot, which instantly removed hydrogen, as shown in the bottom part of (d) and in the rescan image (e). Such manipulations can be used in [[single-molecule electronics]].<ref>{{cite journal|doi=10.1038/srep08350|pmid=25666850|pmc=4322354|title=N and p type character of single molecule diodes|journal=Scientific Reports|volume=5|page=8350|year=2015|bibcode= 2015NatSR...5E8350Z|author1=Zoldan|first1=V. C.|last2=Faccio|first2=R|last3=Pasa|first3=A. A.}}</ref>]]
'''Molecular spectroscopy''' deals with the response ([[frequency spectrum|spectrum]]) of molecules interacting with probing signals of known [[energy]] (or [[frequency]], according to [[Planck's constant|Planck's formula]]). Molecules have quantized energy levels that can be analyzed by detecting the molecule's energy exchange through [[absorbance]] or [[Emission (electromagnetic radiation)|emission]].<ref name="iupac2">{{GoldBookRef|title=Spectroscopy|file=S05848|accessdate=23 February 2016}}</ref> Spectroscopy does not generally refer to [[diffraction]] studies where particles such as [[neutron]]s, [[electron]]s, or high energy [[X-ray]]s interact with a regular arrangement of molecules (as in a crystal).
[[Microwave spectroscopy]] commonly measures changes in the rotation of molecules, and can be used to identify molecules in outer space. [[Infrared spectroscopy]] measures changes in vibration of molecules, including stretching, bending or twisting motions. It is commonly used to identify the kinds of bonds or [[functional group]]s in molecules. Changes in the arrangements of electrons yield absorption or emission lines in ultraviolet, visible or [[near infrared]] light, and result in colour. Nuclear resonance spectroscopy actually measures the environment of particular nuclei in the molecule, and can be used to characterise the numbers of atoms in different positions in a molecule.
== Theoretical aspects ==
The study of molecules by [[molecular physics]] and [[theoretical chemistry]] is largely based on [[quantum mechanic]]s and is essential for the understanding of the [[chemical bond]]. The simplest of molecules is the [[hydrogen molecule-ion]], H<sub>2</sub><sup>+</sup>, and the simplest of all the chemical bonds is the [[one-electron bond]]. H<sub>2</sub><sup>+</sup> is composed of two positively charged [[proton]]s and one negatively charged [[electron]], which means that the [[Schrödinger equation]] for the system can be solved more easily due to the lack of electron–electron repulsion. With the development of fast digital computers, approximate solutions for more complicated molecules became possible and are one of the main aspects of [[computational chemistry]].
When trying to define rigorously whether an arrangement of atoms is ''sufficiently stable'' to be considered a molecule, IUPAC suggests that it "must correspond to a depression on the [[potential energy surface]] that is deep enough to confine at least one vibrational state".<ref name="iupac" /> This definition does not depend on the nature of the interaction between the atoms, but only on the strength of the interaction. In fact, it includes weakly bound species that would not traditionally be considered molecules, such as the [[helium]] [[Dimer (chemistry)|dimer]], [[helium dimer|He<sub>2</sub>]], which has one vibrational [[bound state]]<ref>{{cite journal |author=Anderson JB |title=Comment on "An exact quantum Monte Carlo calculation of the helium-helium intermolecular potential" [J. Chem. Phys. 115, 4546 (2001)] |journal=J Chem Phys |volume=120 |issue=20 |pages=9886–7 |date=May 2004 |pmid=15268005 |doi=10.1063/1.1704638 |bibcode= 2004JChPh.120.9886A}}</ref> and is so loosely bound that it is only likely to be observed at very low temperatures.
Whether or not an arrangement of atoms is ''sufficiently stable'' to be considered a molecule is inherently an operational definition. Philosophically, therefore, a molecule is not a fundamental entity (in contrast, for instance, to an [[elementary particle]]); rather, the concept of a molecule is the chemist's way of making a useful statement about the strengths of atomic-scale interactions in the world that we observe. {{clear}}
== See also == {{div col|colwidth=23em}} * [[Atom]] * [[Chemical polarity]] * [[Covalent bond]] * [[Diatomic molecule]] * [[List of compounds]] * [[List of interstellar and circumstellar molecules]] * [[Molecular biology]] * [[Molecular design software]] * [[Molecular engineering]] * [[Molecular geometry]] * [[Molecular Hamiltonian]] * [[Molecular ion]] * [[Molecular modelling]] * [[Molecular orbital]] * [[Non-covalent bonding]] * [[Periodic systems of small molecules]] * [[Small molecule]] * [[Comparison of software for molecular mechanics modeling]] * [[Van der Waals molecule]] * [[World Wide Molecular Matrix]] {{div col end}}
